events.summary: Alexander Porfiryevich Borodin was born as the illegitimate son of a Georgian nobleman. In a twist of fate, he ended up being registered as a serf, which made his early life a bit of a sitcom in the grand theater of serfdom.
At the tender age of 7, Borodin was emancipated from serfdom by his noble Georgian father, who apparently had a soft spot for his secret son. Talk about a family reunion with a good plot twist!

Borodin enrolled in the Medical–Surgical Academy to pursue a career in medicine and chemistry. Little did they know they were grooming a future composer who would turn medical jargon into musical notes.

Returning from his studies abroad, Borodin became a professor of chemistry at the Imperial Medical-Surgical Academy, where he juggled teaching with composing, proving that some people really can do it all—or at least try to.
Borodin married Ekaterina Protopopova, a pianist, bringing together chemistry and music in a duet that left the audience clamoring for an encore of their life together.

His first symphony hit the stage, conducted by his mentor Balakirev. The symphony was a mix of musical genres and should have come with a 'taste test' warning for audiences not ready for his eclectic style.

events.event: Composed In the Steppes of Central Asia
events.summary: Borodin composed this symphonic poem that perfectly captures the wanderlust of music lovers everywhere, making people daydream of steppes they'd never seen.

He passed away rather dramatically at a ball, as one does when caught between the joys of music and the demands of chemistry, leaving behind unfinished compositions that could've had a cliffhanger ending.

He began the monumental work 'Prince Igor', a daring fusion of music and drama, proving that he could multitask like no other. His efforts culminated in some of the most popular dances that would even make a ballet dancer jealous!

Borodin finally handed in 'Symphony No. 2', a symphonic treat that was like a musical buffet – satisfying and notably a little delayed because, hey, a chemist has to keep those test tubes polished too!
The creation of 'Polovtsian Dances' turned out to be Borodin's jam session, right before he decided to head to the lab, proving that the beat goes on both in chemistry and through music!

compositions.title: In the Steppes of Central Asia
My Songs are Filled with Poison
